content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun problem, perfect for Fastest and Shortest modes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy and fun , truly for coc

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: loved it, its doable in less than 2mins, utilizes concept of lists, loops, logics in Python
I feel like this clash is too difficult to do in Reverse mode. Other than that it looks great :)

Constraints
* Please change "len" to "length".

* Please update the second constraint. The current wording incorrectly implies that 0 cannot be present in [[seq]]. Instead, please change it to:
-1000 ≤ value in [[seq]] ≤ 1000

This range will help players using certain programming languages choose the appropriate variable type.

Cases
* Test 3: Please reverse the order of the input integers (i.e. 6 2 0 -3) so that it's more similar to Validator 3.

* Please shuffle the order of the input integers in these cases:
  • Test 4
  • Validator 4
  • Test 6
  • Validator 6

* Please add a pair of new cases where the input contains at least 20 integers: 0 and negative integers of various magnitudes in random order.

* Please add a pair of new cases where the input contains at least 20 integers: 0 and positive and negative integers of various magnitudes in random order.

Thanks.

Thanks for your feedback! I’ve updated the contribution accordingly. Please note that there’s been a shift in the test numbering: the original test 6 is now test 7 since test 5 now has its negative counterpart.

I see your point of view, and I think it could work well in Reverse mode if we adjust the problem slightly. For example, instead of just solving directly, we could give a sequence of numbers and ask players to guess the next number (or the missing one) based on the logic used to generate the list.
Example:
in_list = [0, 1, 4, 13, 40]
The logic is in_list[i] = 3 * in_list[i - 1] + 1, so the correct output would be 121.
Yes but that would change the entire problem altogether - this problem has a completely different objective, which I find too difficult to deduce in Reverse mode.

Looks good to me. Just one more request: please change the input of Test 1 to -5 -1 3 7, so that the case is more similar to Validator 1.

Thanks again.

I updated the validator instead, but now they should be more similar :).
Thanks again!

Well actually, it's better to do it the other way around. That way, the first pair of cases will be distinct from the others: the input integers will be in ascending order, and it will follow the pattern of making the first pair the easiest to understand (especially for Reverse mode in this clash).
Oh indeed, my bad, fixed again! :)
